questions.question: What does the --dryrun flag do in this command?
options: Runs the sync faster by skipping validation
Shows what would happen without actually copying any files
Creates a dry backup before syncing
questions.explanation: The --dryrun flag previews what the command would do without actually executing it. Essential before destructive operations to avoid costly mistakes.

questions.question: Which command creates a new S3 bucket?
questions.explanation: aws s3 mb (make bucket) creates a new S3 bucket. The s3:// prefix is required. For more options, use aws s3api create-bucket.

questions.question: Which AWS CLI commands can you use to work with Lambda functions? (Select ALL that apply)
questions.explanation: All of these are valid commands: list-functions shows Lambda functions, invoke executes them, logs tail shows CloudWatch logs, and update-function-code deploys new code.

questions.question: What does this command output?
options: All EC2 instances in all states
Only running instances showing their ID and state in a table
The total count of running instances
questions.explanation: The --filters limit to running instances, --query extracts just InstanceId and State.Name, and --output table formats it as a readable table.

questions.question: Match each S3 command with its function:
questions.explanation: cp copies files, sync mirrors directories, mb (make bucket) creates buckets, rb --force (remove bucket) deletes bucket and contents.

questions.question: AWS CLI commands always return all results in a single response, regardless of how many items exist.
questions.explanation: AWS CLI uses pagination for large result sets. Commands may return partial results with a NextToken. Use --no-paginate or handle pagination in scripts to get all results.
